results.notes:
Growing on the ground in mixed woods.
Caps up to 5.6 cm across, dry and partially finely appressed fibrillose.
They had a slight odor; could not identify.
Spore print brown.
Spores ~ 6.1-8.2 X 4.1-5.1 microns, ellipsoid to elongate, smooth.
Gill cystidia present, ~55-75 X 10-12 microns, subutriform to fusoid-ventricose.
Maybe a veiled Hebeloma but spores appear to be too small and too smooth for what I can find in the Smith book.
edit; Henry Beker agrees that the spores are not Hebeloma-like. They appear to have a small germ pore….making Pholiota a possibility.

results.notes:
Growing on a chunk of hardwood mulch in a floodplain. Stem fairly tough and somewhat flattened. Gills not marginate. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis a hyaline cutis and lacking encrusting pigment. Clamps present in the pileipellis. Lamellar trama inamyloid. Cylindrical, hyaline pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia present. Pleurocystidia measurements: (35) 40.3 – 55.7 (70) × (8.9) 10.1 – 13 (16.3) µm, Q = (2.1) 3.7 – 5.4 (6.1); N = 15, Me = 50.4 × 11.9 µm; Qe = 4.4. Cheilocystidia measurements: (22.9) 22.92 – 27.8 × (6.8) 6.82 – 8.4 µm, Q = (2.7) 2.72 – 4; N = 3, Me = 26.1 × 7.4 µm; Qe = 3.6. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (22.2) 22.7 – 30.3 (31.9) × (5.6) 6 – 8 (8.9) µm, Q = (2.7) 3.2 – 4.6 (5.4); N = 20, Me = 26.5 × 7 µm; Qe = 3.8. Spores smooth, hyaline, thin-walled and amyloid. Spore measurements: (5.9) 6.6 – 8 (8.7) × (3.8) 4 – 5.2 (5.5) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 7.2 × 4.6 µm; Qe = 1.6

results.notes:
Growing on a fallen Platanus occidentalis with Pluteus hongoi observation 303453 and Cerioporus squamosus. Fruiting body mostly composed of the anamorphic stage with condia dominating but I was able to find 2 unambiguous basidia (1 clearly visible) and 1 unambiguous basidiospore. Monomitic. Hyphae smooth, simple-septate and hyaline except for the basal hyphae, which were brownish. Basal hyphae up to 10.53 µm wide. Visible basidium seemed to be 4-sterigmate and measured 15.74 × 7.46 µm with sterigmata up to 6.09 µm long. Spore was biapiculate, smooth, hyaline, inamyloid and 7.94 × 5.06 µm. Conidia didn’t seem to be produced in chains. Conidia smooth and hyaline. Conidia measurements from Piximetre: (11.4) 12.4 – 14.7 (16.7) × (8.1) 8.8 – 9.8 (10.5) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.31 – 1.6 (2.1); N = 15, Me = 13.8 × 9.3 µm; Qe = 1.5
Individual conidia: 12.44 × 9.74 µm, 14.32 × 9.79 µm, 11.42 × 8.70 µm, 13.93 × 10.54 µm, 14.09 × 9.11 µm, 13.78 × 9.48 µm, 14.69 × 9.32 µm, 16.66 × 10.00 µm, 12.44 × 9.77 µm, 14.20 × 9.18 µm, 12.11 × 8.95 µm, 16.67 × 8.06 µm, 13.08 × 8.84 µm, 13.59 × 8.84 µm, 14.06 × 8.86 µm

results.notes:
Growing among leaf litter and woody debris in a floodplain. Odor indistinct. Golden yellow to brown rhizomorph tufts present at the base of the stem. Clamps absent. Pileipellis cutis-like with some swollen cylindrical end cells (parts of hairs?). Stipe trama composed of parallel hyphae. Stipitipellis a cutis with some simple-septate, unencrusted hairs with cylindrical to slightly swollen ends. Lamprocytidia absent. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia present as rounded, thin-walled leptocystidia. Cheilocystidia measurements: (12.8) 17.3 – 30.9 (33.8) × (11.1) 11.5 – 22.5 (28.3) µm, Q = (1) 1.1 – 1.5 (2.1); N = 22, Me = 22.7 × 17.6 µm; Qe = 1.3. Brown abortive basidia present. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements from Piximetre: (34.6) 36.2 – 40.3 (44.4) × (10.2) 10.8 – 12.2 (12.9) µm, Q = (2.7) 3.1 – 3.7 (4.4); N = 7, Me = 38.7 × 11.4 µm; Qe = 3.4. results.notes:
Growing in soil among deep hardwood duff and leaf litter in a swamp forest at the edge of a sphagnum bog. Beyond this was a (second growth?) hardwood forest containing many very large Quercus alba. Nearby trees were Acer sacchariferum, Acer rubrum, Fraxinus sp and Alnus serrulata. Quercus spp. and probably other hardwoods further away. Odor not distinctive. Taste farinose and very slightly acrid. Spore print white. Spores hyaline, inamyloid and smooth. Many spores remaining in clumps in Melzer’s reagent. Clumps containing between 3 and 7 spores but most were made up of 4 spores. Clamp connections present in the pileipellis. Hyphae not encrusted. results.notes:
Growing among moss in a hardwood swamp forest at the edge of a Sphagnum bog. Cap and stem dry. Odor not distinctive. Clamps absent in all tissues. Lactifers present in all tissues. Caulocystidia abundant, smooth, hyaline to slightly brownish and variable in shape: ellipsoid, obovoid, sphaeropedunculate, conical or cylindrical. Caulocystidia measurements: (15.5) 17.9 – 41 (47) × (6.7) 9.5 – 16.7 (18.2) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 3.2 (4.6); N = 21, Me = 29 × 13.1 µm; Qe = 2.3. Pileocystidia abundant and similar to the caulocystidia. Lamellar trama inamyloid. Pleurocystidia scattered, smooth, hyaline and very variable in shape: ellisoid, oblong, conical, utriform or tibiiform. Pleurocystidia measurements: (15.2) 17 – 35.5 (48) × (8.1) 8.3 – 13.2 (13.7) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.8 – 3.9 (4.4); N = 14, Me = 28.7 × 10.4 µm; Qe = 2.8. Cheilocystidia scattered, smooth, hyaline and very variable in shape: cylindrical, clavate, lecythiform, lageniform or utriform. Cheilocystidia measurements: (27) 32.7 – 57.4 (61.3) × (8.2) 8.9 – 11 (12.4) µm, Q = (2.5) 3.6 – 5.69 (5.7); N = 10, Me = 45.2 × 10 µm; Qe = 4.5. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth, thin-walled, hyaline and amyloid. Spore measurements: (6.4) 7.2 – 8.8 (9.4) × (4.5) 4.6 – 5.5 (5.9) µm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (2); N = 30, Me = 8 × 5.1 µm; Qe = 1.6

results.notes:
Stipe solid with yellow interior, outside with extensive yellowing nearly to the apex. Slime on stipe leaving many long, peeling fibrils. This specimen was on its own under tanoak and redwood without any suillus or gomphidius basidiocarps nearby. There may have been a couple of Douglas fir in the area. Extensive mud stuck to nearly all the outside. Flesh context white turning slightly pinkish in spots. Cap dull rosy pink. Given the stipe characters, it appears to be one of the two usual species in the area (subroseus or oregonensis). Gills smoky gray and apex white. Taken from sunlit trail. While difficult to clean off, the pileus appears to be unspotted above and the black color is just dirt. Faint sweet fungal/farinaceous odor detected.
Pictures of specimen will be attached.

Photos and information will be posted
Odor: spermatic, but not too strong. A bit of a spicy fungal component.
In conifer/tanoak woods with a few older madrone around.

Brown spores and gills. Finely attached with distinct notch near attachment point.
Stipe base perhaps slightly enlarged, but not much so or bulbous. Crumbled easily and white.
The white on the cap center is not from fibrils.

results.notes:
Pink corticoid crust on root tissue of mature tree (Tulip poplar?) in protected area on cut bank beside trail. Color of photos is roughly accurate of color on site. Crust appears cracked and ‘sugary’ under stereo microscope, not well reflected in stereo microscopy photos due to focus limitations. Microscopy shows globose spores (one with apiculus, one shaped like sesame see) that retain pink color under magnification. Almost no hyphae or other structures seen without cotton blue stain.
Closer examination of basidiocarp shows many inclusions of the ascomycete Chlorociboria! One log nearby stained green from same.

results.notes:
Habitat: occurring singly on deciduous sticks
Cap: diameter 51-80 mm, fan-shaped, tending toward semicircular. Caps dry, glabrous except for short white tufts near point of attachment and a marginal fringe of short, stiff projections almost too stout to be called hairs. Surface texture smooth or weakly bumpy, possibly reflecting underlying tube structure. Cap margin entire or wavy, sometimes lobed. Color whitish to pale cream. Thickness near point of attachment 7-11 mm. Flesh tough, white, not staining. Flesh near point of attachment to 6 mm thick, rapidly thinning to 2-3 mm and tapering to < 1 mm at margin. When dried, caps do not develop radial wrinkles
Pores & Tubes: radially arranged. Pores irregularly angular, averaging 3×1 mm, smaller toward the margin. Tubes to 5 mm deep. Color of both is pale ocher
Stipe: absent or lateral and rudimentary, to 7 mm in diameter, covered with decurrent pores. Flesh tough, white. No black base
Odor: none
Macrochemicals: KOH stains flesh and cap surface ocher
Other: these specimens sporulated freely. Western NC is far out of range for F. brasiliensis, but whatever this is, it’s a frequent find in my neighborhood this week

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1094/2017_DSC03421
Picture file names: from Fomes-fomentarius_raw_10 to Fomes-fomentarius_raw_18.

Habitat: steep mountain slope, south aspect; mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Fraxinus ornus and Ostrya carpinifolia dominant trees; calcareous ground; relatively warm and dry place; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 685 m (2.250 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead, still standing Fagus sylvatica.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; Pod Stemerico place, above Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Fomes fomentarius is probably the most common and easy to spot Polyporaceae in the Trenta valley and surrounding valleys. Only Fomitopsis pinicola living on dead Picea abies is eventually more frequent and also more noticeable with its orange-red rim of the pilei. This is so because deteriorated and rotten Picea abies trees and trunks are in abundance here. Namely, Picea abies is not really a ‘suitable’ species for this habitat and climate and hardly thrives bountifully in this region. Also, many trees now grow on former pastures, now abandoned for decades, which were covered with only a very thin layer of soil. Combined with their shallow root system they are almost regularly toppled by strong winds when they become a few decades old. Presence of many dead Picea abies trunks here around is a stage of natural forest succession process. This conifer is gradually replaced by Fagus sylvatica trees, which is the species truly ‘at home’ in Trenta valley.

The sporocarps on the pictures were found on an old, dead Fagus sylvatica tree. There were more than 35 pilei present, from young ones to very old, decayed ones. The largest is 37 cm wide, 34 cm high and 22 cm thick! The tree has 2.2 m circumference at about half a meter from ground. SP none – fertile only in spring.

Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia
